author: ajcocciolone

title: Makerbot Spool Holder Adapter for Mendel

description.text:
This allows you to bolt a Makerbot Filament spool holder(thingiverse.com/thing:7105) to the top of the Mendel Z-Rod's.
3/4/2012 - I've experienced some issues with my x-axis missing steps off and on with the spool mounted in the first orientation.  Therefore, I designed some additional brackets to re-orient the spool to allow the filament to feed better.  I broke up the bracket into two pieces so it can be printed on a TOM.

• Print out this adapter
  • Print out the spool holder: thingiverse.com/thing:7105
  • Bolt the two pieces together using M3 hardware
  • Bolt to top of the Mendel Z-Rod Clamps using 2 M4x40 Bolts.
    • 3/4/2012 - I've experienced some issues with my x-axis missing steps off and on with the spool mounted in the first orientation. Therefore, I designed some additional brackets to re-orient the spool to allow the filament to feed better. I broke up the bracket into two pieces so it can be printed on a TOM.

I created this little bolt to replace the socket by drilling the old one out, and screwing this one into its place. Needle nose pliers helped tighten it down.

description.text: Experimenting with where to put my ink spool. Sits on Micro 3D printer top edge pretty well. Needs something to hold spool on. Drop leg needs to be about 1/4" longer. All pieces are in this one file, I broke the pieces up to print.

Printer:

Micro 3D

Rafts:

Yes

Yes

Resolution:

250 microns

hollow thick walls

Notes:

I did this in 2 prints because of the size. I used model on model support for the stick, and regular support for the barrel/clip parts. I would use a raft for at least the barrel part. I didn't use the stick because the clip works fine. I used a medium print.

I used electric tape to keep it on. I'm thinking this will be good for the Tough ink, because it's bendy. But I'm running out of the regular hard ink, and it gets really tight around the middle of the spool making it tough to unravel.

I don't know why it keeps posting twisted. Tilt your head to the left.

title: Extended Headphone Stand with Customizable Edge-Lit Nameplate
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
My headphone cables were touching the base after I printed it so i decided to design an extension to put between the base to raise it up. Then I decided to add a name plate, which I lit using "NanoLEDz" from the auto parts store. When customizing the nametag be sure to leave a 5mm space around the text so it fits in the holder.

Note: full disclosure, I used solidworks to make my nametag with a different font which is why it's not available on here.

Notes:

I printed the nametag in clear filament and changed it to black when the letters started printing to get the different colors.
for the edge lighting I screwed in a 12v barrel jack from radioshack and wired it to the Leds which were placed in the channel around the nameplate slot
I designed the extension using solidworks

print_settings.Notes:: I used a 50% infill for PLA to test out this build. I will use the new NylonX in the next build to test different materials.

title: Teach Engineering by Making a 3D Printer!

description.text:
This is a Print It Forward Project from Printrbot that is a great way to teach engineering and basic 3D printing mechanics. Students will learn what BOM means and go through the process of building a 3D printer from scratch.

Update:
I uploaded a V2 of the base. I made it a bit more stable and deep enough to allow for normal size nema motors as opposed to the small motors. Its much more stable.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Printrbot Plus

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

50%

Notes:

I used a 50% infill for PLA to test out this build. I will use the new NylonX in the next build to test different materials.

Students will learn a great deal during this project. Between using metric tools to soldering, some wiring and the concept of rods, bearings, belts, and pulleys. Objectives Student will learn basic engineering concepts by building a 3D printer. Audience High School for a more project based approach. If you want to do lower grades I would make it more of a guided project. Subjects This projects touches most of the STEM subjects. Skills Learned (Standards) Standard 5: Technology
Students will apply technological knowledge and skills to design, construct, use, and evaluate products and systems to satisfy human and environmental needs.

Since this is a project it's more of a hands on lesson/activity. The instructions are pretty detailed but they'll be plenty of opportunity for student to mix things up. The instructions are attached below. Print It Forward:
http://learn.printrbot.com/2016/05/19/print-it-forward/ https://sites.google.com/a/mrwatt.ca/print-it-forward/ BOM:
https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1E4-5YRB7CEhIu44jCj7UVpg7lP5AqpuCChWOlPe01q4/pubhtml All the files for printing can be found here: https://www.youmagine.com/designs/printrbot-labs-kit Quick video of my actual build

This list will be long so I'll try to make it easy. Tools: Torx Screwdriver Set https://www.amazon.com/TEKTON-2830-Everybit-Precision-Electronic/dp/B009MKGRQA/ref=sr_1_5?s=hi&ie=UTF8&qid=1472423266&sr=1-5&keywords=torx+screwdriver+set A fully functional 3D printer with at least a 6" inch build plate. Materials: I will list this in two ways. 1st- The kit is available from printrbot. Here it is: https://printrbot.com/shop/printrbot-starter-kit/ 2nd- The items are listed from different places. This is how I did it because I had a lot of these and didn't want to buy the kit. Belts and pulleys: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00WW256TY/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o04_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 8MM Rod Bearings:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00X9H22SO/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o07_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 8MM Rods: You'll need 6.
4 of these:
https://www.amazon.com/Diameter-8-Hardened-Linear-Motion-Printer/dp/B00WJFR872/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1472423462&sr=8-2&keywords=8mm+rods#customerReviews 2 of these:
https://www.amazon.com/Linear-Motion-Length-Chrome-Hardened/dp/B0045DUX5A/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1472423462&sr=8-1&keywords=8mm+rods Acme Rod:
https://printrbot.com/shop/threaded-rod/ Belts and Pulleys:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00WW256TY/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o04_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 Bearing Pulleys:
http://www.ebay.com/itm/2pcs-Embedded-608ZZ-U-groove-encapsulated-plastic-nylon-Ball-Bearing-8x30x10mm-/131589578531?hash=item1ea3599f23:g:lmEAAOSw3ydV3oOi Printerboard:
https://printrbot.com/shop/printrboard-rev-f6/ Z-Coupler:
https://printrbot.com/shop/z-coupler/ Extruder:
https://printrbot.com/shop/plastic-extruder/ Hotend:
https://printrbot.com/shop/ubis-13-s-hot-end/ Z-Probe:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B008FZC8F2/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 Extruder Motor:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00PNEQ79Q/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o07_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 Axis Motors: You'll need 3 and the connector for it. Both links are below. https://www.amazon.com/Stepping-Motor-26Ncm-36-8oz-Printer/dp/B00PNEQ9T4/ref=sr_1_fkmr1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1472424404&sr=8-1-fkmr1&keywords=Nema+17+medium https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B012EOO9Q0/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 Nuts and Bolts: https://www.amazon.com/GOCHANGE-160Pcs-Metric-Stand-off-Screws/dp/B01C9Q9WEW/ref=pd_sim_sbs_60_7?ie=UTF8&psc=1&refRID=W718TAVXPP2YJ4NTV334 Fan Extension Cable: https://printrbot.com/shop/fan-extension/ Hotend Extension Cable:
https://printrbot.com/shop/hot-end-power-cable/ Hotend Thermistor Cable:
https://printrbot.com/shop/hot-end-thermistor-cable/ Endstops: You'll need 2
https://printrbot.com/shop/18-end-stop/ This is most of the items you'll need I may have missed one. There are plenty of ways to get things cheaper or the solder some of the extension wires yourself. I recommend it but leave it to you since you know your students.
This project should take a few class periods to build. The overall process should be about 4-5 classes.

Teach Engineering by Making a 3D Printer!

This project is a great way to teach students the pride of building something. They'll build a working printer and by doing so understand it's basic mechanics and how to repair it.

description.text:
NOTE: This is for the base game. It has not been tested with the expansion. The brown lids that are concave and can handle heaping mounds of peppers may fit the extra peppers, but I do not know for certain.

Cute pepper containers for the peppers in Scoville board game. Check it out, it is a great game for 2-6 players. In the pictures, the standard lid shows the magnets through the surface, I made it thicker and this should be less of an issue now, It was fine for me because I am painting the lids. (added a picture of all the boxes painted)

All of the pepper colors fit inside 'pepper box with magnets' and the normal 'pepper lid' except for the brown peppers. The brown peppers are more numerous than the other peppers of the same height. For this reason there is a extra lid made called 'pepper lid brown'. That lid is concave and taller which makes room for the extra peppers. They still fit in the tray nice, but they heap slightly. The red/blue/yellow peppers do all fit but you have to sometimes jiggle them around a little, it is a tight fit. If you want more room, just print some extra 'brown lids' for those instead.

The magnets to use are disc magnets, 8mm diameter x 0.8 mm thick. 1 mm thick magnets should work okay too, the lid will just have a slight gap.

If you don't have any suitable magnets, then I also included the design without the mounting areas for the magnets. This version stacks fairly nicely when not in use because of the angled sides. I would suggest buying a batch of rare earth disc magnets on ebay if you have a 3d printer. Magnets are so handy in this hobby, and I find disc/ring magnets to be the most versatile.

Really hope someone gets some use out these!

comments.text: Brilliant! Thanks for uploading this. Are you able to comfortably fit all of these containers in the Scoville box?

This is a simple exhaust port to help get rid of ABS fumes and particles. It's intended to go inside or outside of a 3D printer enclosure. It utilizes activated carbon pellets (easily available at a pet-store) and any HEPA filter material. I've even used a doctor/nurse face mask in a pinch. My enclosure is in my garage which double as a wood shop, so I want to keep dust from getting into my enclosure also.

Basically, fill the "port" with activated charcoal pellets, then put the cap on. If you are placing the port on the outside of the enclosure you will want to sandwich a piece of HEPA filter between the cap and the port to make sure dust doesn't get into the charcoal chamber. Then sandwich the whole assembly to a 12V 40mm PC fan and continue the bolts through the enclosure wall. If you are installing the port on the inside of the enclosure then you will want to put the HEPA filter in between the interior wall and the fan to make sure no dust gets into the enclosure.

Modifying

This should be easy to modify inside of any 3d software. Each item is a separate piece, so one could simply change the date, add a company name (like in the photo) or what have you. Make sure the back plate remains and passes through whatever text you add or you'll end up with spaghetti when the printer just to print into thin air.

This is my 2nd evolution Z-Probe for my Micromake D1 printer.

The 1st probe was simply mounted to the hotend for bed calibration and leveling which requires mounting and dismounting from the effector for every use. Grown tired to that so I designed this new unit.

It simply bolt on to where the original limit switch was and can be swung into action when needed and swung back to the side when not in need. There is a 20mm offset from the nozzle to the probe so when adjusted in the firmware, the maximum bed reach (for probing) is around 60mm only. Do take note.

The two parts are held by a 20mm M3 screw and nut.
Requires a microswitch dimension of 6mm x 13mm.

*** Update 30th August 2016: Replaced the 'mouse-harvested-switch' to a proper snap microswitch. Photos added.

description.text:
I Made this speaker to enjoy a good music while swimming.

The power comes from a cheap bluetooth amplifier board from sanwu (mine is blue without aux in):
http://www.banggood.com/TDA7492P-Bluetooth-CSR4_0-Audio-Receiver-Digital-Amplifier-Board-p-1067571.html

The board is cheap but the sound is really impressive, it´ll be hard to find something better for this price.

I´m also using a 3.5 full range speakers and 3 x 18650 batteries with a protection board:
http://www.banggood.com/10A-Charger-Protection-Board-For-18650-Li-ion-lithium-Battery-Cell-p-1065140.html

In my tests, I used for more than 8 hours without a charge.

To assemble the rotation mechanism you´ll need a m8x35, 3 x m8 washers and 1 M8 self locking nut for each side.

I would reccomend to print using 100% infill to reduce vibration. +- 260 grams of filament to print the entire box.

title: extra board and ball for the game "dimensions"

description.text:
I really like the game dimension https://www.boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/153318/dimension but it only plays up to 4 players due to the limitation of boards and balls.

So I am going to remove the insert and put two more sets of board + 12 balls needed for each player to take it up to a 6 player game.

I will likely buy 25mm marbles for the balls, but I provided an .stl of a 25mm sphere. With supports and some filing/sanding it should print out okay. (lift it off the bed plate for better results).

Since I have a lulzbot mini, I only have about a 6 inch cube to print in, and this had to be split into 4 sections for me to print. I supplied those .stl files as well. I am going to print this in ABS and solvent weld it together with acetone slurry (acetone mixed with abs). I have done similar things before and it works fairly well. It helps if you do it on something safe like wax paper and then after you can put another piece on top and set something heavy on it to make sure it solidifies nice and flat.

I will buy some foam pads from home depot or similar store to raise it up. I could have included them in the print, but I would rather they not be made out of abs.

L'Thondra is a fierce Dragonborn warrior who throws her axes first and asks later. She is in a quest to find her lost mermaid lover. In her belt, she carries her best friend, Pile o' Skulls the goldfish, in a fishbowl.

This is the C-beam Sphinx a strong desktop cnc router that will enable you to cut aluminum plates among other things without taking up to much room. Simple, strong and opensource!

Get yourself a custom set of plates to build your very own Sphinx cnc router.
Available Here.

As always I am providing all the cad and design files free of charge:

If you find them useful in your build or design and want to give back to all the time, effort and materials I put into the design. Feel free to Hit that Tip Icon <-- over on the side. A simple coffee keeps me designing :)

This is of course completely optional and you are free to have the files posted here either way!! :) If you did not find them helpful let me know so I can improve !
​
C-beam Sphinx? The bulk of this machine and every axis is built upon the strong openbuilds C-beam linear rail and much as the Sphinx of myth inherits attributes from many to create one. So do I build from ideas shared with the community.
From Mark Carew with his Ox and Plate Maker, Robert Hummel and his Stinger-V to sm3d and their R7. Each has inspired me to design build and explore this world of cnc that has lead to the design you are now reviewing.
​
Goals with this build:

Many openbuilds parts
Ease of construction
Full documentation
Flexible growth
Strong
​

I would like to think I have reached those goals!
​
The C-beam Sphinx was designed in Sketchup and you will find a full cad model in the attached zip for this build. Along with Sketchup, I have used Fusion 360 to design the new plates of course the .f3d files are also included.

I encourage you to build modify and share your C-beam Sphinx build. Everything you need to get started is within the included zip files.

Along with all cad files you will also find a Cut List , B.O.M , Build Photos and a detailed Build Manual ! While I am no film student I did record and edit a complete Assembly Video to help you along with your own build.

HERE IS THE ASSEMBLY VIDEO

Thank you for reading I look forward to any and all feedback and to following any builds you may take up from my design!

Max material thickness / clearance can be adjusted with changes in the spoiler board sizes. I am currently running a base of 1/2" mic-6 tooling plate 1" mdf replaceable spoiler board and I mounted my z-axis lower then I had to by a 1/2".  Leaving me with roughly 1.250" of material clearance. Raising the Z axis and going with thinner spoiler boards can get me a lot more if needed.

remixed_from.author: GunghoLabs
remixed_from.title: Sturdy Leg With Adjustable Foot For Kossel

title: Sturdy Leg With Adjustable Foot For Square Printers
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I really liked the original design, but I don't have a Kossel printer, I have a custom-made printer with 90° angles.

Since I had it on-hand, I used 1/4-20 hex bolt and nut in place of the original hardware.

One more trick that I used: I printed the foot's pad with NinjaFlex. I was able to do this by first printing the foot pad with PLA and the nut's cavity facing the build plate. Then I sliced the Ninjaflex pad separately @ 1mm height, and manually offset the z-axis value in the GCode file by the foot pad's printed height, and VOILA! I have an integrated grippy ninjaflex pad on the bottom of my sturdy foot!

I have also included the SolidWorks 2014 files if anyone wants to further play with this model.

remixed_from.author: DestinyStlGenerator
remixed_from.title: Destiny Exotic Shotgun Lord of Wolves 1:1 Scale

description.text:
My oldest daughter wanted to learn how to make things with our 3D printer. She was a bit ambitious and decided to make this gun from her favorite game Destiny. She wanted it for cosplay. Together we took the original posted by DestinyStlGenerator and used 3DS Max to smooth out the model. It's not perfectly smooth and can use some more work in a few places, but it was good enough for our needs. You can print as is, or work a little more on the model if you would like.

We figured we would post our work here for others that may be interested in making the prop. This should save everyone a fair amount of time.

We included the smoothed out model and the sliced model to print on a smaller printer like ours.

title: E3D V6 Magnetic Mount for Radial Fan Duct
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I really liked rniice's remix (thing 1274039) of the snap-in blower fan by esteevens, but I wanted to mount it magnetically to my E3D cooling fan. The mating mount comes from thing 1165614, so you can grab it there.

My fan uses Ø3/16" x 1/16" magnets. they are a pain to press into place, but are great once in there!

I also included the SolidWorks source files if people want to further play with this one. The edge of the blower was REALLY close to the heating block (made from PLA), so I added some aluminum tape to help reflect the radiant heat. Seems to be holding up, for now, but I may fix it up some more.

description.text: This is a collet based telescope adapter for a smartphone. The collet sleeve is designed to be glued to the back of a smartphone case, so the telescope eyepiece can be repeatably positioned with the collet. The nut has 4 threads to aid in expedient eyepiece changes, and the collet is sized to fit most standard 1.25 inch telescope eyepieces.

Printer:

XYZ Printing Pro 1.0

Rafts:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Printed in PLA at 40 mm/s. No supports were needed during printing, as all overhangs are small, and well supported from below.

Smoothing

Post processing may be required on the inner and outer surfaces of the collet, as well as on the inner tapered surface of the collet sleeve to allow the collet to clamp the eyepiece effectively. Fine grit sandpaper worked well for this.

Without this step, the collet can only move one print layer at a time over the sleeve. Because of this, optimal clamping may not be achieved and the eyepiece may slip.

title: In-halo - inhaler for children with asthma
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Asthma is usually a cause of bullying. Inhalers symbolize weakness. This inhaler becomes a friend, the child builds a bond of empathy. No more shame. The use of this inhaler motivates children to learn and treat their condition.

This inhaler was originally designed focused on small children with asthma - the grip is easier. However, after feedback from parents I learned most children use spacers. There are some spacers that have a rubber end that adapts with any inhaler's mouthpiece. If that is the case, this inhaler still works with that. I also learned there are several sizes of canisters, so it might not fit all of them.

Printer:

XYZ DaVinci Jr.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

15

Notes:

Use best quality possible, at least for the main part (the base).

Use a needle or pin to perforate the spray hole. It will be marked in the print but because of the size, most printers won't make a clean hole through.

The tolerances for fitting the top on the base might not be perfect due to printing quality and method. You can sand or use a knife to remove excess material and make them fit together.
I designed this for GrabCAD.com's 3D Printing Event in 2012. It won the first place out of hundreds of entries from all over the world.

This model has been online for free download since 2012. There have been attempts to steal it and commercialize it, but all have failed so far. Please support the original design and author (me :) ). It was never my intention to get money out of people with this, but to offer an alternative to traditional inhalers.

Thanks to everyone who has supported me. This is for everyone.

description.text: So i builded myself a Prusa i3 and i had a lot of problem with the x-axis, the default x-carriage that can be found on the Prusa github (https://github.com/josefprusa/Prusa3/tree/master/box_frame) have 3 bearing, 1 for the upper bar and 2 for the lower. All i did was modify the original scad adding a 4 bearing, now all bar have 2 and at least for me worked like a charm. In the file you can find the 3 standard version of the carriage (30,50,80) for Gt2 and T2.5 belt, i added the .scad if anyone needed to change something. FYI, this carriage can probably cause some clearance problem with some extruder, right now im using this one http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:65939 and it works greate.

title: Marvin Printer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is, of course a work in progress. It's my take on The FlexMendel which pulls some ideas from TAZ printers, but simplifies things as FlexMendel intended. The build volume is 285mm x 275mm x 270mm. The Z could probably go higher, but that is what I have my marlin firmware set to at the moment. The XY could be bigger if I had a completely flat piece of glass; the mirror I'm using is beveled near the edges, which cuts down on my overall print area.

The extruder assembly I remixed from ffleurey, but I tried to minimize the sagging of the X-Rails by rotating the motor 90 degrees and trying to center the motor's weight over the X-rails as best as I could. It improved things, but right now, I still can only print about 7-8" in the center of the platform (along the X-axis).

For the most part, I simply used 8020 hardware, since I had a bunch of it on-hand.

I put up some of the STL files, but not all of them. I'll try to upload more as I have time (and motivation) to do so. Until then, enjoy!

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Used honeycomb infill pattern for overall strength. Some of the parts were printed on the Marvin Printer once it was up and running.

Background

I liked the overall design of the FlexMendel printer, but I did not have 2020 extrusions. I DID, however, have 8020 brand extrusion in their 1010 profile, or 1" square, so I re-created all of the parts in SolidWorks 2014. I have the STL files posted here. The source models are not exactly the same, because I've been designing upgrades and did not save the original files.

For the extruder, I liked the TAZ style removable carriage, so I replaced the FlexMendel carriage with that. PLUS, the X-axis rail width was the same :D. To help reduce the X rails being twisted and reducing the available print area along the X-axis, I turned the motor 90 degrees and tried to place its Center of Gravity (Cg) between the rails as much as I could. What I'm working on now is upgrading the X rails from 8mm to 12mm.

As for the print bed, I used TAZ model because A) I wanted a larger print bed and B) I had 12" square mirror panels that I saved from a bathroom remodel. I also decided to use a NEMA 23 stepper motor to move the print bed. I was losing position, and I chose to go with a larger motor to counter that. The standard A4988 stepsticks work just fine with the larger motor; no overheating issues at all! To simplify the motion, I decided to use 8020 linear bearing pads (which appear to be made from teflon) for both the Y-axis (print bed) and Z-Axis movement. The extrusions seemed to be very straight, so why add the cost & complexity of additional rails + bearings?

I originally used M8 threaded rod, but the rods I had were WAY too wobbly for my taste, so I bought some step motors with 400mm long, 4mm pitch lead screws integrated into the motor shaft: http://www.robotdigg.com/product/245/Tr8*4+400mm+Leadscrew+Threaded+17+Stepper

They were well worth the $40 and shipping (I believe they have a $30 flat-rate shipping for up to 2kg, so I shopped their sight to max out the 2kg :D).

For the Z movement, I used 8020 sliding blocks in place of the machined sliders the FlexMendel uses on the X ends, and changed the size of them (width-wise) along with some PTFE shims to take up MOST of the play. It's still a bit wobbly, but it's pretty repeatable if the system is constantly moving the z-axis in only one direction. I don't get much of the banding that I've seen on some prints posted to Thingiverse, anyway.

The LCD mount is for thing 861091; look there for those STL files.

description.text:
I was looking for some medieval Shoulder protection for me and my kids... after looking around, I didn't find something that could handle my kids play style ;)... so I take this as an opportunity to fire up my freecad and design something new!

Here is the resulting product! Look great , could be wearied without any shame :)

I've printed them scaled at 60%, 65% for my kid and 85% ( need a large bed) for me

You also need to print pivot cover at the same scale...

After print, free the pivot ,paint it using a permanent gold maker(eg. Sharpie work well),glue the cover on the pivot , and glue a leather band inside the biggest plate to attach it to the costume...

Printed using silver filament and painted gold part using a gold sharpie ( permanent marker)

I've added the freecad file so you could made custom pivot cover, or change the design... have fun!

You should also take look a my other design (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1804922) or (http://www.thingiverse.com/Stonedge/designs)

Hope this would made some little knight happy! If you made it, please post pics!

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Tevo tarantula with large bed and flsun kossel

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Number of shell 3

The stl contain 5 independent part(3 Armor plate and 2 pivot) that are already correctly positioned (and the required support for pivots are already included)

So open the stl with your favourite slicer, scale it to your needs and print!

Scale example:
Scaled at 60% = internal distance between pivot of 145mm
Scaled at 65% = internal distance between pivot of 155mm

With a pair of long nose plier or a small flat screwdriver, pop out the small pivot support triangle. Turn both pivot to be sure they're free from the three Armor plate.

Glue the pivot covert and the top strap, fix it to your favourite medieval costume and enjoy!

comments.text:
I found a guy on YouTube that showed me how to do it.
You need two spools to begin with.
Begin by almost emptying one, leave between 3 and 7% left.
On the other empty it fully.
Now remove both chips from each cartridge(do not get them confused)
Make a switch that can 'switch between each chip.
So start a print with the one that has 7% . The machine will say there is not enough material to continue, want to continue anyway.
Say yes and flick your switch so it reads now the empty chip
That's it.

description.text:
This is a model of the art deco stainless steel eagle gargoyles on the Chrysler Building in New York City.

I originally modeled this in Sketchup to be made out of sheet metal, so it is a little blockier than the actual sculpture.

The model in the picture is printed at 35% scale with 0.15 mm layer height.

UPDATE (09-MAR-2017):
The original OBJ file had some issues with disconnected faces and flipped normals (thank you Sketchup :(). The new STL file is completely manifold.

UPDATE (26-NOV-2017):
I added a decimated version of the object file. This file is about 1/4 the size of the original.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker Original

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.15 mm or less

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Rotate the model so that the nose is upward to minimize supports.
I originally designed this in Sketchup to be made out of card stock or sheet metal, so the shapes were created to ultimately be made into flat patterns.

description.text: I wanted to start taking time lapses of my 3d prints and realized that I needed something to illuminate the underside of the extruder for the webcam I am using to take halfway decent video. I had some of these USB LED Lights that I bought from eBay and decided to use those since they are very bright and very compact. I designed it for the Monoprice maker Select and you can either mount it to the unused Y-Axis Endstop or the back of the Drag chain mount since the screws for that protrude enough to screw into the mount.

This is a small air pump designed to push air into 3/8 ID rubber tubing. You can easily design your own adapter if your needs require something different.

The motor I used for this is a Turnigy 1400kv brushless out runner motor. It's commonly used in quadcopters and requires an speed controller to run. It might be kind of overkill for this application so feel free to edit this to fit a different motor. I've included a STEP file for this purpose.

To get my model to run I bought a cheep esc, lipo battery, and servo tester from hobby king.
If you are into quadcopters you probably have all this stuff and know more about it then I do so use what you think is best, but here is the stuff I bought.
Motor
Servo Tester, this one was kinda glitchy so you may want to get a different one.
ESC, the motor calls for a 40 amp esc and this is only 30 so get whatever you feel like.
Just get any kind of lipo battery to run it, I used this one.
You're also gonna want 19 of 4-40 x 3/8 machine screws.

Video

title: Parts to make an MF8 3x4x5 cuboid puzzle fully functional.

description.text:
These are the parts required to make an MF8 3x4x5 cuboid puzzle actually fully functional. Despite it being called that the standard version really isn't due to bandaging issues with the internal central layer.

You really only need to print 3 of each. I made extra for testing purposes. They seem to be working very well in my puzzle but printer tolerances/accuracy differences might not provide the same results for you.

To fix the puzzle partially dissemble it and replace all of the large internal edges with the exception of the one that has the hook piece on it with a pair of these then reassemble and enjoy.

Video showing it actually being fully functional now.
https://youtu.be/FwF0kahRpg8

Video showing a very leisurely solve after modification.
https://youtu.be/jZQaaVpzfZo

I'm very capable of reproducing the entire cube but that's not something I am willing to do.
The main reason is that its not my intellectual property to share. Reverse engineering something doesn't make it mine to do whatever I want with. I didn't design the cube. I just fixed something about it and as such I feel as though I can share the fix. Supporting the actual designers of puzzles is important to me. I have much respect for TomZ. Morally I couldn't release that sort of thing unless he specifically said he was OK with me doing so and I wouldn't be so rude as to ask him. If you want one I suggest you save the money up and buy one. Sorry...

remixed_from.title: Otto DIY build your own robot

title: Otto DIY Robot (Modified by Jason Workshop)

description.text:
Who is Otto?

An interactive robot that anyone can make!
Otto walks, dances, makes sounds and avoids obstacles.

Is completely open source, Arduino compatible, 3D printable, and with a social impact mission to create an inclusive environment for all kids.

Otto was inspired by another robot BoB the BiPed and programmed using code from another open source biped robot Zowi.

CC-BY-SA

Otto's differences are in the assembled size (11cm x 7cm x12cm), cleaner integration of components and expressions. Using off the shelf and 3D printed parts, simple electronics connections (almost no welding required), and basic coding skills, you will be able to build your own cute Otto friend in as little as two hours!

Otto is design using Autodesk 123D Design software you can modify it for customization or further improvements!

Gather all the off the shelf parts that you'll need for this assembly.

List of parts:

Arduino Nano, preferable with the pins already weld it
Arduino Nano Shield I/O Extension Board Expansion XD-212
Mini usb cable. (most Arduino dealers provide the cable)
HC-06 Bluetooth Board Module (4-Pin)
HC-SR04 Ultrasound sensor.
Mini servo SG90 9g x6 (each one should come with 2 pointed screws and one small screw).
5V Buzzer.
Female to Female breadboard connectors cable 10cm x 10.
4 AA (6V) Battery case
1.5V AA batteries x4.
Mini cross screwdriver. important magnetized
And then you only need to 3D print 8 parts in total:

3D printed head.
3D printed body.
3D printed left arm.
3D printed right arm.
3D printed left leg.
3D printed right leg.
3D printed left foot.
3D printed right foot.

For the programming:

Download & Install Arduino IDE:
https://www.arduino.cc/en/Main/Software
Copy Oscillator libraries to C:\Users\user\Documents\Arduino\libraries (or wherever your library folder is installed):
Finally open & upload OTTO_smooth_criminal.ino code to your Arduino Nano for dancing Otto.
More codes in https://github.com/OttoDIY/

Or follow this instructable http://www.instructables.com/id/Otto-Build-You-Own-Robot-in-Two-Hours/ that focuses on how to build the Otto DIY, more Ottos are coming and you can stay tuned for updates by subscribing on http://www.ottobot.org

Printer:

idBox

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Recommended to use a FDM 3D printer with PLA material. You can print individually piece by piece to match the colors of the original design or optionally print all at the same time.

author: avikshit

description.text:
One of my first prints with my new 3D printer. It was a quick model I created Autodesk Fusion 360 as part of testing the 3D printer. It's a way for nerdfighters to share their nerdfighter pride. :)

For those that aren't in the nerdfighter community, DFTBA stands for "Don't Forget To Be Awesome". Even if you're not a nerdfighter, it's a good philosophy to live by!

Scanned with the MakerBot Digitizer Desktop 3D Scanner  
Using the new multiscan feature to capture more of the surface of difficult to scan objects.  I've included a "before" single scan as well.  
Those wide flat wings cause lots of occlusions on a single scan.  With Multiscan, you can move the object around the platform and do multiple scans that get automatically merged into one.  
If you're having problems printing because bottom is not flat, try the new file I just uploaded called angels_multi_flat.stl

description.text:
This is a screw terminal box for the screw terminals you can grab at the nearest hardware store. I didn't like how the terminals were supposed to fit in ready-made boxes, so I've made a different one that features two separate compartments for both terminals, so that you'll never have a short circuit.

Solvespace sources are provided if you need to adjust sizes.

Printer Brand:

Solidoodle

Printer:

Solidoodle 2 - Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

honeycomb 30%

Notes:

Add a few mm of brim, you bed must have a good adhersion, or the box will warp during print. Better to use ABS, since PLA is never used for such enclosures.

Assembly

Insert the screw terminals and secure them with stock M4 bolts. The box is designed in a way that M4 bolt heads will be sunk into the plastic.
Mount it on the wall using 4.2x19mm self-tapping screws. After connecting all the wiring secure the cover with M3 bolts.
WARNING: Make sure that the wall surface is NON-CONDUCTIVE, especially if you are connecting the mains AC voltage. You may want to insulate those bolts with some sticky tape on the back side. For added water resistance apply silicon sealant on between the box and the top cover and on all holes.

remixed_from.title: Landru Cable Carrier w/ opened links

description.text:
Yet another cable chain for 3d printers, cnc mills, laser cutters, robots ... and everything that needs electricity on moving parts.
My cable chain is heavily inspired by Landru's cable chain (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10915) and a remix of it (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10934). They should be compatible to my one as well. What I changed:
  • rounded shape on the outside (just because I like the look)
  • multiple endings with different options to mount.
  • open links are not that wide open as the remix of Landru's are.

I printed it with .2mm layer height without support with PLA.
Male endings are symmetric, female ones are not.

author: Vigomat

description.text:
An engine oil separator. Designed to take 12mm-1/4NPT barbs (holes for barbs are 12.25mm to thread into). Put a copper brillo pad or steel wool on the OUTSIDE of the box in the lower right corner. Provides a labyrinthine path for the oil to escape and for oil vapor to recondense. Pair with an off-the-shelf PCV on the top vapor output or on the bottom side vapor input, but not on the bottom oil drain/airbox connection. Must be mounted vertically so the slopes all align.

Assemble either with acetone welding, or black oil-safe RTV, or cut your own gasket out of cork.

As seen on:
https://stupidbus.wordpress.com/

title: Sinner Spirit recumbent (ligfiets) chain tube holder

description.text:
My wife's Sinner Spirit recumbent bike worked very well, but for one thing. Having shortened the length of the boom to suit the length of her legs and having installed a larger chainring, the chain line was no longer straight, with the chain direction being altered by the chaintube itself. This resulted in a considerable amount of noise and drag from the chain running through the chaintubes.

This 3D printed part allows the chain tube to run closer to the mounting bolt than is possible with the stock metal part, and it allows for adjustment so that the chainline can be straight. Much quieter and more efficient.

See other special parts for recumbent bicycles in our webshop http://www.dutchbikebits.com/recumbent-velomobile-parts

description.text: Soprte para servo y fin de carrera para cualquier prusa i3 rework o derivados, yo uso el extrusor compacto http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:715496 y ya que todo es compacto pues el auto nivelador también tiene que serlo. En cuanto al servo es uno pqueño, marca protech como los que usan los aparatos teledirigidos pequeños y encaja perfectamete con las medias a 21mm x 11,5mm pero como tiene mucho uso tambien le he pegado con cinta se doble cara por dentro.

RepRap

Prusa i3 V

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

-

Una vez impresas todas las piezas se monta el servo en elsoporte, luego hay que quitar las tuercas inferiores del soporte del extrusor y se monta la pieza con el servo, el brazo y el fin de carrera, también montados se dejan sueltos y se da corriente a la impresora para que el servo se ponga a 0, entonces montas el brazo con el fin de carrera en la posicion alta y puedes empezar a ajustar los parametros de tu firmware.
This object took 30 minutes to make with lots of boolean or subtractive objects for the windows.  It prints real nice, scale it up for best results or slow your printer down for a smaller size.

I made this building with Eureka, by adding simply primitives to create the base structure, columns and dome, the windows are subtractive objects, that cut away parts of the main object.  However in Eureka the mesh is not destroyed so you could make lots of variations with almost no effort at all.

description.text:

The inside fit is quite tight, but should loosen upon use. That´s also why I made a solid wall on one side, that allows tapping the BB cup for easier removal if it gets stuck.

XYZ Jr. 1.0

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

3mm

Infill:

90%

Notes:

Just rotate so the opening faces up. No supports required. Feels pretty solid on PLA.

Measured diameters from tool and Shimano bottom bracket, created design in Fusion 360 by creating radial patterns of the notches.

Made a test print that resulted in the outside notches too small, so corrected by increasing the notch diameter and adding fillets, and offset by 11.25ª to allow for more rigidity.

title: Stryker M1128 Mobile Gun System Battlefield

description.text:
Following the end of the Cold War some theorists believed that the existing suite of U.S. armored vehicles, designed largely to fight Soviet mechanized forces in Europe, were not well suited to the lower-intensity missions U.S. armed forces would be tasked with. This led to the development of a new armored fighting vehicle designed for lower-intensity combat, rather than large-scale battle. However, vehicles derived from the LAV III and its predecessor the MOWAG Piranha have been found to be vulnerable to weapons such as the RPG-7, requiring the improvisation of slat armor to defeat anti-tank rockets, while main battle tanks have proven to be invulnerable to all but one rare type of RPG-7 rocket (the PG-7VR). Canada had liquidated about half of its fleet of Leopard 1s in the early 2000s, with the intention of replacing them with the airmobile Mobile Gun System. The decision was reversed. In fall of 2006 a squadron of Leopards were sent to Afghanistan, and in 2007, the Canadian Army acquired 100 surplus Leopard 2 main battle tanks from the Netherlands for quick deployment.

Full-rate production has been indefinitely deferred as of 2012.
The U.S. Army allocated nine Mobile Gun Systems to a battalion. There were 27 Mobile Gun Systems per Stryker Brigade in 2013, but the Army is cutting the number per brigade to 10. The Army bought 142 Mobile Gun Systems in total three were lost in combat. A three-vehicle MGS platoon operates organic to a Stryker infantry company, with one MGS in support of a Stryker infantry platoon or operate as a platoon or allocated to rifle platoons as necessary

Battlefield is a series of first-person shooter video games that started out on Microsoft Windows and OS X with its debut video game, Battlefield 1942, which was released in 2002. The series is developed by Swedish company EA Digital Illusions CE (DICE) and is published by American company Electronic Arts. The series features a bigger focus on large maps, teamwork and vehicle warfare than most traditional first-person shooters.

A simple test print which has bridges of lengths: 3mm, 10mm, 20mm and 30mm.

comments.text: Nice! I doesn't use much material!
comments.author: Jaknil

comments.text:
Indeed I have printed 6 of them in some green PLA, only 1.75g worth of material on average per object.
I ended up printing 6 as I noticed a very slight tendency towards warping / not sticking to the print surface in the ends.
I measured the print bed surface temperature and decided to increase it 10C (to just below the glass temperature for PLA) which seems to have fixed the problem.
I printed 4 in one session to make sure that the bridge performance was not just a lucky coincidence.
Long story short, perhaps they also serve sort of as a warping test?

description.text:
The Turning Torso is a neo-futurist residential skyscraper in Sweden and the tallest building in Scandinavia. Located in Malmö on the Swedish side of the Öresund strait, it was designed by Spanish architect, structural engineer, sculptor and painter Santiago Calatrava and officially opened in 2005. The tower reaches a height of 190 metres (623 ft) with 54 storeys and 147 apartments.

There is a plain model and a model with built in supports. I haven't figured out the best way to print this yet I think, but the supports version works OK, except for making the back spline a bit jagged on my printer. If you have a good slicer you might get better results just using the normal model and using the slicer's supports. Note that the plain model will not print without supports because there are large overhangs.

comments.text: There is no doubt that this fan nozzle is a game changer for a 3drag owner. I mean, it's easy to print and it actually delivers air where it's needed. Thank you!
comments.author: giogio

comments.text:
Lovely.. just. Lovely.
I bought some cheap PLA thinking "How bad can it be". Getting the balance between heat in the Head, the Bed and stopping the thin overhangs of models curl was proving to be, ahem, frustrating. This got the cool just where I needed it. The design is lovely, clearly a lot of thought went into this which is probably why it also looks so very pretty.
Thanks
comments.author: MrTheKod

comments.text:
Very good solution, especially because it is mounted from behind and it is no longer in the way of the sight of the printed thing.
A forward stroke: Adapters for 40 x 40/50 x 50 fan. I killed already two of the "atomy" ones!
comments.author: rowa

comments.text: Needed a longer screw (M4, at least 20 mm) to be able to mount the nozzle. I also had to heat the PLA with a lighter at the corner where the screw used for mounting the fan will sit (one screw is enough) and press it a little bit inwards, to have enough room to fit a nut on the screw. In the same way, I heated the tip of the nozzle as it was a little bit too low and might have collided with the print objects.

Just the head hollowed out. still working on fully hollowing it.

After getting back from camp this year I decided to make a friendship bracelet holder that would work better than a water bottle and this was the result. It has eight pegs which each can hold one bracelet (or more if you want), and a magnetically attached top so that it's easy to take off or put on bracelets, but they won't fall off on their own. My idea was to cover the bottom in microsuction tape (google it, you can get a sheet for $15), but you could also do anything you want to secure it like getting a small clamp or just putting something heavy on top of it.

BTW, all the bracelet designs in the picture came from friendship-bracelets.net, which is a great website for finding new patterns.

Materials

There are two holes in the top and bottom for 1/8" neodymium magnets, which you can get from K&J magnetics here: https://www.kjmagnetics.com/proddetail.asp?prod=B222
I would recommend gluing them in using 5-minute epoxy, but make sure you have the orientation right before gluing or it won't work.
